Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2010 11:53PM dalycity wrote: Hi, Barbara: Welcome! Are you pre- or post-menopausal? At the time I was diagnosed at age 55, my surgeon told me that any one of the following could warrant chemo: Grade 3, pre-menopausal, and/or PR-. Of course, it also would depend on everything else on the pathology report. They want to hit it hard initially with chemo, you know, so hopefully it won't come back. It's good you are getting a second opinion. Here's a big hug to you; and I hope you get more input from others pretty soon.
Posts.Title: New Diagnosis - Chemo or Hormones chanellygirl chanellygirl

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 01:40PM dalycity wrote: Hi, DM and Ann:  I have a similiar diagnose too (12/06).  Post-meno, 55 y.o.; tumor 1.2 cm, Stage 1, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/:R+, Her2-. Treatment is lumpectomy, clear margins, radiation (20x) & Arimidex for 5 years. Both opinions said no chemo (my surgeon and UCSF).  Actually, even my radiologist said no chemo. I asked about doing oncotype-my surgeon said not necessary (I will ask him why at my next appt. just for my info); and UCSF did not suggest it. My surgeon did say that if I were pre-menopausal or Her2+, he would recommend chemo.  All the best to you.
Posts.Title: Oncotype score - CHEMO? dm2573 dm2573

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 10:45AM dalycity wrote: Dear BlueMama: Are your post-menopausal? Cancer usually is less aggressive in post-meno. What about the other characteristics of your tumor? Such as Her2 status, ER/PR+? These other issues would weigh in on your decision; but I would definitely get a second opinion before I decide.  Of course, as Sandy says above, I would want to know what each doc recommends. Best wishes to you.
Posts.Title: Borderline for Chemo BlueMama Cindy1960

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 09:55AM - edited Sep 5, 2008 09:57AM by dalycity Dear Ganga: I am so sorry to hear this. You did say that docs thought she has about 6 months to live. But the fact that she has negative PET scans, which is good news, why is he putting her in palliative care? Badboob is correct; there are many, many options available to late stage cancer.  Seems the docs have to try everything possible.  Are you or your sister able to call her doctor with your list of questions? Such as why won't chemo work for her; other options for her, etc.? I am so sorry about the prejudicism in HK.  My prayers are with you and your SIL.  Best wishes,

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 06:32PM dalycity wrote: I think with any hard mass if you push it enough, it will move.  That was what I was trying to convince myself when I found a mass (tumor, as it turned out to be in my case); I kept moving it and pushing it and of course, it moved.  So I told myself that oh look, it moved so it must be a cyst and not a tumor. Wrong. I agree with Leaf; only way to be sure is go see your doctor; otherwise you'll just be guessing.
Posts.Title: how do you tell if your lump is mobile? mommycjk dalycity

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 10:20AM dalycity wrote: Dear Imrunner: I am so sorry you have to go through this. I remember my second opinion doc said that with an Oncotype, you cannot "hang you hat on it".  My main breast specialist doc told me he would make the chemo recommendation based on various factors - age, menopausal status, tumor over 2cm, and of course, Oncotype, etc. You do have good news with negative nodes and Grade 1 status. The doctors go by their experience and education, and make their best educated recommendations based on that. No one really knows if chemo will help a particular person or not.   I hope you will get a second opinion.  Good luck to you in your decision.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2007 07:58PM dalycity wrote: Dear Irishstep: I remember before I was diagnosed, I kept feeling my lump and it seemed to keep changing size and shape! And only way of course is a biopsy, which was done in the doctor's office, not difficult at all, kind of like giving blood. Oh, you brought a smile to me when I read that you were embarrassed to show your big breasts to nurses & radiologists; well, I was embarrassed to show my SMALL breasts to them! The whole BC ordeal for me was scary of course; but throughout my whole treatment, I reminded myself that I have to do the best that I can; and that I have to leave alone the things I cannot control.  I wish you all the best.
